title: Jue
subtitle: The Ritual Wine Warmer
content: A jue is used to serve warm wine during rituals. Its particular shape—flared, pointed, triangular legs; ovoid body; long curved spout counterbalanced with a pointed flange; and two columnar protrusions—makes jue one of the most easily identifiable ancient Chinese bronze and pottery vessel forms. In later periods, jue were still made for ritual use and Qing-dynasty (1644–1912); examples often have elongated legs.

title: Ding
subtitle: The Three-legged Cauldron
content:
The ding is a three-legged cauldron used for cooking or sacrificial offerings. During the Western Zhou, the ding evolved from a purely ritual vessel into a potent emblem of state power and legitimacy.

The number of ding a noble could possess was strictly regulated by rank: emperors were entitled to 9, feudal lords to 7, ministers to 5, and scholar-bureaucrats to 3 or 1. This system made the ding a visible marker of social hierarchy and authority.

title: Sword
subtitle: 剑
content:
Swords became the most iconic bronze artifacts of this period due to advancements in metallurgy and the shift toward infantry-based warfare.

These weapons were not only functional but also artistic masterpieces.

title: Figurative Forms
subtitle: Objects Shaped Like Humans or Animals
content:
Human-shaped bronze artifacts became prominent during the Qin and Han dynasties, which reflects the advanced techniques of bronzeware casting.

These figures were often used in burial contexts or as ceremonial objects.
